description.en: Free action, once per turn: spend 1 Treasure to search for Stealthed Assets. Pick a faction and make a Cunning vs. Cunning attack. No counterattack on failure. On success, all Stealthed Assets of that faction within one move are revealed.
Skilled fortune-tellers and minor oracles foresee perils and enable swift counterattacks.
Free action, once per turn: move any allied Wealth or Cunning Asset in same location to a destination within movement range, even if the destination wouldn't normally allow a non-Subtle Asset.
Disposable minions. If another Asset within one move is struck by an Attack, sacrifice the Useful Idiots to negate the attack entirely. Only one band of Useful Idiots can be sacrificed per turn.
Hostile factions in the same location can't roll more than one die during Attacks made by or against them there, even if tags or Assets normally grant bonus dice.
Immune to Attack or Counterattack damage from Force Assets, but cannot defend against Force Asset Attacks.
Free action, once per turn: spend 1 Treasure to grant a Wealth Asset within one move the Subtle quality. Lasts until the Hired Friends are destroyed or use this ability again.
An Asset Attacked by Saboteurs can't use any free action abilities during the next turn, whether or not the Attack succeeded.
On a successful Attack, the targeted Asset cannot leave the Charmer's location until the Charmer moves or is destroyed. Immune to Counterattack.
Free action, once per turn: pay 1 Treasure to move any Cunning or Wealth Asset at the same location. The transported Asset gains Stealth until it performs an action or is otherwise used.
Magically-gifted spies and assassins. Always begin play with the Stealth quality.
A veteran operative runs a counterintelligence bureau in the area.
Automatically grants 1 Treasure to its owning faction each turn.
Easily-manipulated hotheads enlisted under whatever ideological or religious principle best enthuses them for violence.

Instead of an Attack action: spend 1d4 Treasure and attach to a hostile Asset in the same location. Until destroyed, infesting another Asset, or leaving, the target Asset cannot be used for anything and grants no benefits.

Whenever another faction moves a Stealthed Asset into a location within one move, Vigilant Agents may make a Cunning vs. Cunning attack against the owning faction. On success, the intruding Asset loses Stealth after completing the move.

Instead of an Attack action: make a Cunning vs. Cunning attack on a specific hostile Asset within one move. On success, the target can't do anything or be used on its owner's next turn. No Counterattack on failure.
Sleeper agents and deep-cover spies burrowed into hostile organizations, waiting to disrupt them from within when ordered.
Free action, once per turn: spend 1 Treasure to grant the Shapeshifters the Stealth quality.
Non-Stealthed hostile units cannot enter the same location without paying 1d4 Treasure and waiting one turn to arrive.
A religious prophet, charismatic philosopher, rebel leader, or other figure of popular appeal firmly under the faction's control.

A network of secret transit extending far around this Asset. Free action: pay 1 Treasure to move any friendly Asset from a location within one move of the Roads to a destination within one move of the Roads.

On a successful Attack: this Asset is lost, owning faction gains 5 Treasure, and the targeted Asset switches sides. The conversion happens even if the new owners lack the attributes normally required for that Asset.

Free action, once per turn: force a rival faction to reroll a check, Attack, or other die roll and take whichever result the Mindbenders prefer. A faction can only be affected this way once until the start of the Mindbender's faction's next turn.

Any friendly Asset may move into the Popular Movement's location, even if normally forbidden and lacking Subtle. If the Popular Movement later moves or is destroyed, such Assets must also leave or suffer the usual consequences for a non-Subtle Asset.

Whenever the faction's Assets make a Cunning roll, they may reroll a failed check at the cost of inflicting 1d6 damage on Just As Planned. May be done repeatedly (possibly destroying it). No range limit.

At the start of their turn, each hostile Stealthed Asset within one move must succeed in a Cunning vs. Cunning check against the owning faction or lose Stealth. All Cunning rolls by the faction for units or events within one move of the Seers gain an extra die.
Judicious exercises of force intimidate the locals, making them reluctant to cooperate with any group opposed to the faction.
Ordinary citizens enlisted into night watch patrols and local guard units. Most effective defending from fortified positions.
A sorcerer has summoned a magical beast or mentally bound a disposable assassin into the faction's service.
Gutter ruffians and common kneebreakers organized in service to the faction.
Locals aided by trained guerrilla warfare leaders who help them sabotage and attack unwary hostiles.

Skilled teamsters, transport ships, or road-building crews. Free action, once per turn: bring an allied Asset within one move to this location, or move an allied Asset from this location to a target within one move. Multiple Military Transports can chain movement over long distances.
Retired military personnel and rear-line troops spread through the area as workers or colonists, available to resist hostilities.
Long-range scouts and reconnaissance experts able to venture deep into hostile territory.
Carefully-selected skilled warriors given magical armaments and arcane blessings to boost their effectiveness.
Common foot soldiers organized and armed by the faction. Not particularly heroic, but numerous.
Fanatical servants of a cult, ideology, or religion who wreak havoc without thought for their own lives. After every time they defend or successfully attack, they take 1d4 damage.
Personnel trained in detecting traitors, spies, hostile magic, and hidden spellcraft within the organization.
Mounted troops, chariots, or other mobile soldiers. Weak on defense, but can harry logistics and mount powerful charges.
A network of roads with logistical stockpiles. Once per turn: move any one Asset from any location within reach to any other location within reach for 1 Treasure.

Specially trained to build bridges, reduce fortifications, and facilitate lightning strikes. During a Relocate Asset action, it can move itself and any allied units at the same location to any location within range, even if the unit type would normally be prohibited. Relocated units may remain there even if the Vanguard Unit leaves.

Can only Attack assets and locations reachable by waterways. Once per turn, can freely relocate to any coastal area within movement range. Must be based at a landward location for supply and refitting.
An inhuman assassin-beast summoned or constructed by powerful sorcerers to hunt the faction's enemies. Enters play Stealthed.
An advanced web of magical Workings, skilled sorcerers, and logistical experts. Free action, once per turn: repair 2 HP of damage to an allied Force Asset.
Soldiers trained in trenching, sapping, and razing. On a successful Attack, the target's owner loses 1d4 Treasure and this faction gains it.

Organized fortification and supply caching around the Asset's location. Once per turn, when an enemy Attacks targeting the faction's Force, the Fortification Program can defend if it is within one move of the attack.
Elite warriors of considerable personal prowess — noble sympathizers, veteran members, or amenable mercenaries.
Mobile war machines driven by trained beasts or magical motive power.
A leader for the ages. Whenever the Brilliant General or any allied Force Asset in the same location Attacks or defends, it rolls an extra die.
Rigorous mental inspection and counterintelligence measures. Can only defend against attacks targeting the faction's Cunning, but grants an extra die to defend.
Magical creatures designed for warfare, or greatly altered humans. Few and elusive enough to evade easy detection.
A hideously powerful ancient super-weapon unearthed from a lost armory, raining eldritch horror on targeted enemies.

A truly irresistible military organization. During a Relocate Asset action, can move to locations that would normally prohibit formal military forces, as if it had the Subtle quality. It is not, however, in any way subtle.
Hired caravan guards, bodyguards, or other armed minions serve the faction.
If another faction creates an Asset at this location, the cost increases by 1 Treasure. This penalty stacks.
Farmers, hunters, and simple artisans. Free action, once per turn: roll 1d6; on 5+, gain 1 Treasure.
On a successful Attack, the target faction loses 1 Treasure (if any) and the Front Merchant's owner gains it. Only once per turn.
Free action, once per turn: spend 1 Treasure to move itself and one other Asset at the same location to a new location within one move.
Interpreters and cultural specialists. A faction taking Expand Influence at this location rolls an extra die on all checks there that turn. Free action, once per turn: move this Asset.
Legal specialists who turn local laws against the faction's enemies. Cannot Attack or inflict Counterattack damage on Force Assets.
The roughest, most brutal laborers organized to discipline the faction's enemies.
A magical mechanism from ages past refitted for industry. Whenever an Asset in the same location must roll to make a profit (e.g., Farmers, Manufactory), roll twice and take the better result.
The faction's Magic is counted as one step higher for creating Assets at this location. Multiple Laboratories in the same location stack.

Hired mercenaries. Free action, once per turn: move itself. Requires 1 Treasure upkeep at the start of each turn; if unpaid, roll 1d6: on 1-3 the Asset is lost, on 4-6 it goes rogue and attacks the most profitable target. Repeated each turn until paid or lost.
Free action, once per turn: roll 1d6. On 1, lose 1 Treasure; on 2-5, gain 1; on 6, gain 2. If Treasure is lost and none available by end of turn, this Asset is lost.

Whenever an Asset within one move is destroyed by a Force-based Attack, the owner may pay half the destroyed Asset's purchase cost (rounded up) to instantly restore it with 1 HP. Cannot restore Bases of Influence.
Free action, once per turn: target an Asset in the same location. Its owning faction must pay 1 Treasure or lose the targeted Asset.
Can only Attack or inflict Counterattack damage on Assets that require at least Low Magic to purchase.
For each Usurers unit owned, Asset purchase costs may be decreased by 2 Treasure (minimum half cost). Each use inflicts 1d4 damage on the Usurers from popular displeasure.

Free action, once per turn: move. Free action, once per turn: sacrifice the Mad Genius to treat the Magic rating at this location as High for purchasing Assets. Boost lasts only until the next Asset is purchased there.

Free action, once per turn: move itself and one Asset at the same location to any water-accessible location within one move. The co-moved Asset gains Subtle until it takes an action at the destination.

Free action, once per turn: make a Cunning vs. Wealth check against an Asset in the same location. On success, the owning faction must pay Treasure equal to half the target's purchase cost or the target is disabled until paid.
Free action, once per turn: move itself without cost.
Free action, once per turn (before buying a new Asset in the same location): the Merchant Prince takes 1d4 damage and the purchased Asset costs 1d8 Treasure less (minimum half normal price).
Bold traders. Free action, once per turn: accept 1d4 damage to earn 1d6-1 Treasure.
An ancient workshop with magical tools. Free action, once per turn: the Ancient Workshop takes 1d6 damage and the owning faction gains 1d6 Treasure.
If an Attack reduces an enemy Asset to 0 HP, the owner may immediately pay half the target's purchase cost to claim it as their own, reviving it with 1 HP.

A vast array of carters, ships, smugglers, and caravans. Free action: spend 1 Treasure to move any friendly Asset within two moves to any location within one move of either the target or the Transport Network.
Free action, each turn: gain 1d6 Treasure usable only to repair damaged Assets (as the Repair Assets action). Unspent Treasure from this is lost.
Free action, once per turn: move. Requires 2 Treasure upkeep at the start of each turn, or goes rogue as the Free Company. Cannot be voluntarily sold or disbanded.
Assets requiring Medium+ Magic roll attribute checks twice against this faction during Attack and take the worst roll.
All purchased Assets enter play with the Stealth quality.
Once per turn, can use Expand Influence as a special ability instead of a full action.
Can purchase Assets as if attributes were 2 points higher. Max 2 such over-complex Assets at any time.
Rolls an extra die for all Cunning checks. Cunning must always be its highest attribute.
Rolls an extra die for all Force checks. Force must always be its highest attribute.
Auto-wins attribute checks if its attribute is more than 2x the opponent's, unless the opponent is also Massive.
Faction turn movement range is doubled.
Assets costing 5 Treasure or less cost 1 less (minimum 1).
Rolls an extra die for all Wealth checks. Wealth must always be its highest attribute.
Inflict HP damage on enemy assets/bases equal to your total Force + Cunning + Wealth.
Destroy a rival faction.
Choose an undamaged rival Asset. Destroy it within 3 turns. On failure, pick a new goal without the usual turn of paralysis.
Plant a Base of Influence at a new location.
Have Stealthed assets in rival Base locations equal to your Cunning score. Already-Stealthed units when this goal is adopted don't count.
Destroy a Force asset with a minimum purchase rating higher than your Force.
Don't take an Attack action for 4 turns.

goals.difficulty: half avg of ruling faction's attributes, rounded up

description.en: Destroy a rival's Base of Influence in a specific location.
Choose Wealth, Force, or Cunning. Destroy rival assets of that type equal to your score.
Spend Treasure = 4x your Wealth rating on bribes. Money is lost, goal accomplished. Must increase Wealth before selecting again.
